Hi Dean,

Welcome to both lists. I will try to answer a few of your questio=
ns very
simply. You can see photos of contemporary mounts for the period in=
 question
in the Tokyo National Museum publication Uchigatana Koshirae. You=
 will see
there that the earlier wraps are done in leather, typically a dar=
k green or
blue along with black and the lacquered over. The same is also l=
acquered
black and the saya are leather wrapped and also lacquered black. T=
suba are
typically plain iron, there is a simple fuchi, more decorative men=
uki,
sometimes in gold or with a lot of gold foil coverings and a black-lac=
quered
horn kashira with the handle wrap going over the tip of the kashira.=
 Katana
typically have a kogai in the saya and the saya have a distinctive =
round
kurikata and an "obi-hook." As you move into the Momoyama period wrap=
s and
saya get gaudy with multicolored leather wraps, red saya and what not=
. I
suggest you get the uchigatana book, which will answer all your questio=
n
visually.

Gordon

Dear All,

This is my first post to this list, and before asking my ques=
tion I felt
that it would make sense for me to briefly say a little about m=
yself and
what I do, so that you can better respond to my queries.

I run a=
 tiny historical re-enactment society here in the UK, which is
trying to po=
rtray the period of first contact between Europeans and the
Japanese (1543-=
1640) to a reasonable degree of authenticity. For an
illustration and a mor=
e detailed explanation please see the link at the
foot of this email.

As p=
art of our general aim to gradually improve the quality of all our
equipmen=
t, one of our number Tracie Anderson, has been learning the art
of kumihimo=
, and she has got quite good over the last few years. So much
so, that her =
husband Simon, has decided that he wishes to have his sword
rebound in a si=
lk braid of her making. Likewise several others of our
group are now beginn=
ing to form a disorderly queue.

Now, as to my first question; during the p=
eriod 1500-1640 is there any
evidence for tsuka ito being made with other t=
han plain colours? 

All the surviving examples that I've seen to date, are=
 bound with plain
colours, but this could be a function of later re-binding=
 fashion, or
the fact that I have really poor eyesight:-) 

Today, you see =
in numerous kumihimo books, a huge range of multi-
coloured patterned braid=
, but they rarely if ever give a date for their
introduction. On armour you=
 see the so-called "woodpecker" style used
for the mimi-ito and the herring=
bone type used as part of the trim on
quality foundation fabrics, but that'=
s it, as far as I know that is.
I've seen plenty of modern fancy sageo offe=
red for iaitou, but I have no
idea if this is an in-period or a modern feat=
ure.

Tracie has made flat braid with spiral, diamond, herring bone, and a
=
host of other patterns and is about to try her hand at woodpecker. She
can =
work with up to 16 different colours at the moment, but is having
some more=
 bobbins made to enable her to go up to as many as 32 if needs
be.

As we a=
re about to embark upon having several new custom weapons made
here in the =
UK, with decent iron fittings, including replica Owari
sukashi tsuba, it wo=
uld be nice to have all the braid hand made in
correct period patterns (ass=
uming they existed), so that they look more
like 16th/17th century swords r=
ather than modern iaitou. Although the
fittings are correctly hand forged h=
ere in the UK, the blades we use are
sadly not traditionally crafted. They =
are individually made by a UK
smith, with blunt edges and durability as the=
ir prime requirement. This
is because they are used for mock combat, which =
does involve some
contact. It would be a crime to wreck a correctly made pi=
ece of art in
such an encounter, and that's leaving aside the issue of the =
expense.

Now for my next question; is there any evidence for simple iron f=
ittings
for tachi or han-dachi?

All the tachi that I have come across in b=
ooks and museums, have been
mounted with various forms of fine gilt fitting=
s, which is only to be
expected, as the common run of the mill type equipme=
nt rarely survives
(again assuming that they existed in the first place). G=
ilt fittings
would be of too high a quality for the class of warriors that =
we are
currently trying to recreate. Most of us carry uchi-gatana as you wo=
uld
expect, but it would be nice to have the option on mounting the blade i=
n
han-dachi koshirae, or having a tachi made. I understand that some no-
da=
chi were reputed to have had rather poor iron  fittings, but I have no
idea=
 if such things were ever applied to the tachi of the lower or
middle ranki=
ng mounted warriors. 

Incidentally, we will be having a no-dachi made, sta=
rting very shortly,
which should be finished in a few months, assuming ever=
ything goes well. 

Finally, a slightly frivolous question; in combat, the =
only swords we
have that actually "ring" upon their occasional contact with=
 another,
are of purely symmetrical design. Asymmetric weapons, like rapier=
s and
katana do not ring at all. Now in movies like the Twilight Samurai an=
d
Ran, there can be heard the "ching" of blade to blade contact, leaving
as=
ide any issue of technique, is this just the director having the
effect dub=
bed in because the audience expect to hear it, or does the
real thing ring?=
 My expectation is that they would not, for as I
understand it, it is the e=
nergy oscillating to and fro across a
symmetrical weapon that produces the =
pure note, just like a bell. I ask,
because when giving talks upon Japanese=
 history etc. I often get asked
why our swords do not ring as in the movies=
. I give the above
explanation, but if this failure to ring is merely a fun=
ction of poorly
made replicas, and I'm wrong about the real thing, I would =
really like
to know, so I can avoid making a twit of myself in front of a
p=
otentially educated audience!

Okay, that's it, any suggestions, advice, he=
ckling?

Yours

Dean
